dataset.title: Tree heights and diameters: Wickersham fire sites (at the Viereck thaw probe locations), 1995 and 2004

address.deliveryPoint: USDA-Agricultural Research Service PO Box 757200 University of Alaska Fairbanks
Boreal Ecology Cooperative Research Unit University of Alaska Fairbanks School of Agriculture and Land Resources Management P.O. Box 756780

abstract.para:
In June of 1971, the Wickersham fire burned 6313 ha in an open black spruce forest underlain with permafrost and provided an opportunity to study fire and fireline effects on the rate and patterns of permafrost, soil, and vegetation recovery. When wildfire burns through a northern black spruce forest the degree of soil organic layer consumption greatly influences the post-fire community characteristics. The construction of firelines with heavy machinery involves the complete removal of vegetation and the soil organic layer down to mineral soil and likewise affects the community characteristics after fire and fire suppression. This long-term study is part of a comparison between the vegetative communities of firelines, burned, and unburned open black spruce forests underlain by ice rich permafrost. In this study, tree diameters and heights were measured in an unburned control plot and in a heavily burned plot. There were no trees to measure in the fireline plot.
Tree heights and diameters at breast height were measured for tree species in the heavily burned and unburned control sites on the east side of Cushman Creek of the Wickersham Fire Sites. This dataset focuses on the trees of the east side sites (2004 and 2130) to corroborate the detailed studies of active layer depths and fireline surface level changes previously published (Viereck, 1982; also see datasets in related material section) and in preparation.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: Tree heights and diameters at breast height were measured in the heavily burned (2004) and unburned control (2130) sites on the east side of Cushman Creek in 1995 and 2004. The fireline (2012, between the unburned and burned stands) where vegetation and organic material were removed down to mineral soil contained no trees, so was not measured. At each site on the east side, ten fiberglass poles were previously established as permanent active layer thaw probe points at 2m intervals on a transect perpendicular to the fireline. In the heavily burned stand (2004), we measured trees in a 100 m2 circular plot (5.6m radius) centered on thaw probe pole #5. In the unburned control stand (2130), due to the high density of trees, we measured trees in a 50 m2 half-circular plot (5.6m radius) centered on thaw probe pole #5. We measured trees in the lower half-circle, down slope from the thaw probe line. This dataset largely focuses on the trees of the east side sites (2004 and 2130) to corroborate the detailed studies of active layer thaw and fireline surface level changes previously published (Viereck, 1982) and in preparation. This dataset does not cover the established sites on the west side of Cushman Creek: a lightly burned black spruce stand (2001), a heavily burned black spruce stand (2002), an unburned black spruce stand (2003), and the fireline (2010) between the heavily and lightly burned stands. The west side sites and additional sites on the east side were monitored by Joan Foote as part of the Institute of Northern Forestry long-term vegetation monitoring that included point-centered quarter methods for measuring tree diameters and heights.

section.title: Methods
section.para: Tree heights and diameters at breast height were measured in August of 1995 and 2004. In each circular or semi-circular plot, diameters (cm) at breast height (1.4 m) were measured for all tree species. In 1995, tree heights were estimated for all trees in the heavily burned plot (2004). In 2004, tree heights were measured with a laser or telescoping pole for representative diameter classes in the heavily burned (2004) and unburned control (2130) plots.

dataTable.entityDescription: Tree heights and diameters at breast height were measured for tree species in the heavily burned and unburned control sites on the east side of Cushman Creek of the Wickersham Fire Sites.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Tree number in plot (trees are not tagged or labeled)
Diameter measurement in cm at breast height (1.4 m)
